channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Going Home to Falluja, a City Slipping Back Into Turmoil
item.media:description: A returning resident of Falluja with police officers.
item.media:credit: David Zucchino for The New York Times
item.description: Times journalists visit a former ISIS stronghold and find it struggling to recover. Residents feel angry and abandoned, and militant attacks have resumed.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ZUCCHINO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Today in Mosul: Retaken Parts of ISIS Stronghold Return to Life
item.description: Visits this week in the eastern part of the city show security forces in control and civilians returning. But signs of Islamic State rule are everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Photographs and Text by RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: French Farmer Who Aided Migrants Is Given Suspended Fine
item.media:description: Cédric Herrou outside a court in Nice, France, on Friday after receiving a relatively mild punishment for assisting migrants.
item.description: Cédric Herrou, 37, has become something of a hero for challenging the official policy of rounding up those who cross the border illegally.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Taboo Italian Thinker Is Enigma to Many, but Not to Bannon
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon referred to the Italian philosopher Julius Evola in a Vatican speech in 2014.
item.description: Julius Evola was a darling of Italian Fascists and has caught on in the far-right circles Stephen K. Bannon nurtured at Breitbart News and harnessed for President Trump.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: ‘We Want a Better Life in a Better Country’
item.description: Elena Filip is one of tens of thousands of Romanians who have taken to the icy, cold streets of Bucharest to demand government accountability.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA and YARA BISHARA

item.title: Trump’s Visit With Shinzo Abe Is Intended to Show Warm Ties With Japan
item.media:description: President Trump in the Oval Office on Thursday for the swearing in of Jeff Sessions as attorney general.
item.description: They plan to talk about trade and security at a working lunch at the White House before heading to Mr. Trump’s Florida resort to play golf and relax.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Trump, Changing Course on Taiwan, Gives China an Upper Hand
item.media:description: President Trump boarding Air Force One in Florida on Sunday. Mr. Trump’s reversal on Taiwan could mean a tougher negotiating position in Beijing on trade, North Korea and other issues.
item.description: In pledging to honor the “One China” policy, the president may have averted confrontation with Beijing, but some said he also sullied his reputation there.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Rich ‘Apprentice’ Host in Politics? But This Mayor Says He’s No Trump
item.media:description: Mayor João Doria of São Paulo, Brazil, center in white cap, helped plant a tree in the Vila Carrão neighborhood on Sunday. He took office in January.
item.media:credit: Marcio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Using attention-grabbing tactics, João Doria, the new mayor of São Paulo, Brazil, has cast himself as an outsider prepared to shake up the political scene.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Kenyan Court Blocks Plan to Close Dadaab Refugee Camp
item.media:description: Part of the sprawling Dadaab refugee camp, north of Nairobi, Kenya, in 2015. A Kenyan judge ruled on Thursday that the government’s plan to close the camp was discriminatory.
item.description: A judge ruled that the government’s plan to close the world’s largest refugee camp was discriminatory. The vast majority of refugees who live there are Somalis.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: A Bilingual Cameroon Teeters After English Speakers Protest Treatment
item.description: Demonstrations against the government, which is dominated by French speakers, have led to arrests and at times to violence.
item.dc:creator: FRANCOIS ESSOMBA and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Hong Kong Subway Fire Injures Over a Dozen
item.media:description: Injured people receiving medical treatment on Friday inside a subway station in Hong Kong.
item.description: A man believed to be mentally disturbed started a fire on a train during the Friday evening rush, according to the police. They said there was no evidence of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Iran Celebrates Its Revolution, Toning Down Anti-American Messages
item.media:description: Students waved the Iranian flag during a rally in Tehran on Friday to celebrate the anniversary of the 1979 Islamic Revolution.
item.description: The National Day celebration seemed calculated to avoid further inciting President Trump, who has lashed out against the Islamic republic.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: 4 People, Including 16-Year-Old Girl, Held in French Bomb Plot
item.description: The authorities “do not know where nor how” the suspects arrested near Montpellier had planned to carry out an “imminent” attack.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Hundreds of Pilot Whales Die After Beaching in New Zealand
item.media:description: Volunteers trying to keep alive some of the pilot whales beached at the northern tip of New Zealand’s South Island on Friday. Officials said it was one of the country’s largest whale strandings.
item.description: Rescuers tried to send the whales back out to sea, but at least 250 died in what officials called one of the worst whale strandings in New Zealand’s history.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Hans Rosling, Swedish Doctor and Pop-Star Statistician, Dies at 68
item.media:description: Hans Rosling giving a TED Talk in 2010. He was a self-described “edutainer.”
item.media:credit: Katie Orlinsky for The New York Times
item.description: Inviting animated visualizations and prosaic props (like apples and Lego plastic blocks) defined him as a funky philosopher rather than a geeky professor.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Widening Crackdown, Egypt Shutters Group That Treats Torture Victims
item.media:description: Magda Adly, right, of Al Nadeem Center for Rehabilitation of Victims of Violence at a news conference in Cairo last year. “I don’t understand how a regime with an army and a police force can be scared of 20 activists,” Ms. Adly said in a phone interview after the Egyptian government shut down the group’s offices.
item.description: The shutdown of the offices of Al Nadeem Center for Rehabilitation of Victims of Violence is the latest escalation in a campaign against human rights and civil liberties groups.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Trump and Abe to Talk: Why They Are Meeting and What They’ll Discuss
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan during a ceremony at a base north of Tokyo last year. He will meet with President Trump on Friday in the Oval Office.
item.description: President Trump and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan will meet in Washington, and they’ll probably broach trade and defense ties, targets of critical Twitter posts by Mr. Trump.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Paris to Increase Security Around Eiffel Tower
item.media:description: Soldiers on patrol at the base of the Eiffel Tower in January 2016.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: As a major tourist destination that has endured several deadly terrorist attacks in recent years, Paris wants to ensure that millions of visitors feel safe.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Exiled Former President of Maldives Plans to Seek Office Again
item.media:description: Former President Mohamed Nasheed of the Maldives in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Thursday. “I can contest, I am a Maldives national, and I am free — I must be free to contest,” he told reporters.
item.media:credit: Ishara S. Kodikara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Mohamed Nasheed faces obstacles, notably his conviction in 2015 on terrorism charges that his supporters say were politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Russian Airstrike Kills 3 Turkish Soldiers in Syria in ‘Friendly Fire’
item.media:description: Rebel fighters on the outskirts of the northern Syrian town of Al Bab on Wednesday.
item.description: The attack injected new tension into a volatile corner of the Syrian battlefield.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Greece Pressured to Improve Migrants’ Living Conditions
item.media:description: A baseball stadium built for the 2004 Summer Olympics in Athens is now filled with tents for migrants.
item.description: Human rights groups have criticized the country’s situation at its camps for migrants after protests and three deaths during cold weather.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations High Commission for Refugees

item.title: Trump May Turn to Arab Allies for Help With Israeli-Palestinian Relations
item.media:description: An Israeli settlement in the West Bank. President Trump initially presented himself as an unstinting supporter of new settlement construction, but he has tempered that position somewhat.
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.description: The emerging approach mirrors the thinking of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, who visits Washington next week, and also of past American administrations.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and MARK LANDLER

item.title: Dutch Get Creative to Solve a Prison Problem: Too Many Empty Cells
item.media:description: De Koepel prison in Haarlem, the Netherlands, which recently housed migrants.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: In a nation where about a third of cells sit empty, the Netherlands has rented some to other governments, and it has turned some jails into refugee shelters.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Mr. Darcy, You’re No Colin Firth
item.media:description: Colin Firth, right, in his turn as Mr. Darcy, and an illustration of what his character may have looked like in the 19th century.
item.description: A study posits that Mr. Darcy, Jane Austen’s character in “Pride and Prejudice,” would’ve looked “more ballet dancer than beefcake” in the 19th century.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: U.S. General Seeks ‘a Few Thousand’ More Troops in Afghanistan
item.media:description: Gen. John W. Nicholson Jr. testified before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Thursday.
item.description: The commander of the international military force in Afghanistan said they were needed to train and advise Afghan soldiers.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 2 Arrested in Central Germany on Suspicion of Plotting Attack
item.media:description: Boris Pistorius, the interior minister of the German state of Lower Saxony, said the raids were “a very important success” in the battle against terrorism.
item.description: An Algerian and a Nigerian were detained in Göttingen, a university town in Lower Saxony, and a machete and guns were confiscated.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Memo From Bobigny: For Roma in France, Education Is an Elusive Path to Integration
item.media:description: A Roma family at a camp near Noisy-le-Grand, outside Paris. While there is consensus that public education could help integrate a Roma population that has long faced systematic discrimination, the obstacles remain formidable.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: While there is consensus that public education could help integrate a Roma population that has long faced systematic discrimination, the obstacles remain formidable.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN de BOURMONT

item.title: Burn an American Flag? Some Iranians Are Saying No
item.media:description: Iranians burned an American flag outside the former United States Embassy in Tehran in 2011.
item.description: Anti-American talk is common in Iran, but the backlash against actions by President Trump has prompted some Iranians to take a different view.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Trump Tells Xi Jinping U.S. Will Honor ‘One China’ Policy
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China in Lima, Peru, last year. The fact that President Trump and Mr. Xi had not talked since Mr. Trump took office in January had drawn increasing scrutiny.
item.description: President Trump and Mr. Xi, the Chinese leader, spoke by phone on Thursday evening after an extended chill in the two countries’ relationship.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: In Romania, Corruption’s Tentacles Grip Daily Life
item.media:description: A protest in front of government headquarters in Bucharest, Romania, on Sunday.
item.description: In a country that has made news for large-scale corruption protests recently, favoritism and bribes color everything, and can mean life or death.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Feeling ‘Pressure All the Time’ on Europe’s Treadmill of Temporary Work
item.media:description: Cristian Meiler is fluent in five languages and has a degree in hotel management. Despite decades of experience, he never managed to land a prized full-time job.
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.description: In the European Union, more than half the new jobs since 2010 have been through temporary contracts, creating more workers seeking full-time employment.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: Opinion: What We’re Fighting For
item.media:description: United States Army soldiers transported Iraqi detainees captured during Operation Steel Curtain in 2005.
item.description: Our acts of moral courage defend America as surely as any act of violence.
item.dc:creator: PHIL KLAY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Germany’s Political Void
item.media:description: President Joachim Gauck of Germany last month. “Freedom, when it becomes normality, seems trivial,” he said.
item.description: Joachim Gauck, the departing president, is one of the last reminders of the country’s dark past. Can he be replaced?
item.dc:creator: ANNA SAUERBREY

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Am I Imagining This?
item.media:description: President Trump in the Oval Office this week.
item.description: The truth under siege: 2+2≠5.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
